title: Present Simple
description: The Present Simple tense describes habits, routines, general facts, and scheduled events. Understanding its forms and uses is essential for everyday communication, providing clarity and accuracy when talking about regular actions or timeless truths.

subtopics.title: Affirmative Statements
subtopics.description: Basic positive sentences using the base form of the verb (add –s/–es for he, she, it).

examples.explanation: Used with I, you, we, they.

subtopics.title: Negative Statements
subtopics.description: Express that something does not happen or is not true.

examples.explanation: Negative form for I, you, we, they.
Negative form for he, she, it.

subtopics.title: Yes/No Questions
subtopics.description: Questions that can be answered with yes or no.

examples.explanation: Question form for I, you, we, they.
Question form for he, she, it.

examples.sample: Yes, I do. / No, he doesn’t.

subtopics.title: WH- Questions
subtopics.description: Information questions starting with what, where, when, who, etc.

examples.explanation: Question form for I, you, we, they.
Question form for he, she, it.
When ‘who’ is the subject, use the base verb plus –s if needed.

subtopics.title: Third-Person Singular –s
subtopics.description: Special spelling rules for he, she, it forms.

examples.explanation: Change y to i and add –es.

subtopics.title: Frequency Adverbs
subtopics.description: Adverbs showing how often an action happens, usually placed before the main verb.

examples.sample: I usually go to bed at 11.

subtopics.title: Habits and Routines
subtopics.description: Using the Present Simple to describe repeated actions or schedules.

examples.sample: He walks to work every day.
We visit our grandparents on Sundays.

subtopics.title: Facts and General Truths
subtopics.description: Statements that are always true or scientifically factual.

exercises.instruction: Rewrite in the negative form of the Present Simple.
